newsitem.title: FRANCE: Saudis put final touches to marathon barley deal.
newsitem.headline: Saudis put final touches to marathon barley deal.

text.p: Saudi Arabia was putting the final pieces in place on Thursday morning for a $140 million grain deal to buy a million tonnes of barley for its animal herds this autumn, European grain traders said.
Negotiations to supply the world's largest barley importer, now in their third day, have dragged on longer than usual because of the heavy response to an international tender.
One trader estimated the total amount of barley offered at four million tonnes, of which the kingdom's buyers must sift through the best offers to match volume, dates and price.
"That's why it is taking so long, but I would say it is being done this morning," the trader said.
Traders said on Wednesday that the best offers to supply the barley were at $142 per tonne including the $20-22 cost of freight as well as colouring necessary for Saudi barley imports.
A small proportion of imported barley must by dyed red to meet Saudi rules for distinguishing it from the local crop.
Traders said the final deal was likely to emerge in a range between $142 and $146 or $148 per tonne, worth $120-122 and upwards as an fob departure price for grain exporters.
That is considered cheap by several traders -- one of whom called the tender a "bloodbath" on prices -- but others point to the sharp recent fall in world wheat and corn values.
U.S. soft red winter wheat was pegged overnight at $130 per tonne and U.S. no.2 yellow corn at $109, both for September.
Fob export barley has recently been quoted around $130 per tonne fob and Iran on Wednesday bought a far smaller quantity of 50,000 tonnes of barley for October shipment at $127-128, fob.
The Saudi purchase tender is for one million tonnes of barley from any export origin to be delivered in September and October.
The European Union, Canada, the U.S. and Australia are among the leading exporters likely to supply the barley.
